ubx_message.name: UBX-RXM-RTCM
ubx_message.description: RTCM input status: This message shows info on a received RTCM input message. It is output upon successful parsing of an RTCM input message, irrespective of whether the RTCM message is supported or not by the receiver.

bitfields.name: crcFailed
bitfields.description: 0 when RTCM message received and passed CRC check, 1 when failed

bitfields.name: msgUsed
bitfields.description: 2 = RTCM message used successfully by the receiver, 1 = not used, 0 = do not know

payload_fields.name: subType
payload_fields.description: Message subtype, only applicable to u-blox proprietary RTCM message 4072

payload_fields.name: refStation
payload_fields.description: Reference station ID (valid range 0-1023 for RTCM 2.3, 0-4095 for RTCM 3.3). Reports 0xFFFF if not applicable.

issues: Labels byte 6 as Reserved instead of msgType
Labels byte 6 as Reserved instead of msgType
Incorrectly identifies msgUsed as a U2 field at byte 2
Labels byte 6 as Reserved instead of msgType
Labels byte 6 as Reserved instead of msgType

valid_variations.reason: In some High Precision (HPG/HPS/LAP) documentation branches, the msgType field at offset 6 is labeled as Reserved, though the underlying payload length remains 8 bytes.

structure.description_note: This message is deprecated. Use UBX-RXM-COR instead.

valid_variations.reason: Later firmware versions (e.g., TIM 2.25 and LAP 1.50) deprecate this message in favor of the newer UBX-RXM-COR message.

adjudication.reasoning: Across 13 sources, there is a strong consensus on the 8-byte payload structure. The fields 'version' (0), 'flags' (1), 'subType' (2), and 'refStation' (4) are consistent. Most sources identify byte 6 as 'msgType', while a subset of High Precision (F9-HPG/HPS/LAP) manuals label it 'Reserved'. Extraction 8 is identified as an error because it shifts the 'msgUsed' bits into a standalone U2 field and omits the 'refStation' field entirely, contradicting all other 12 manuals. Newer firmware manuals (Extractions 5 and 9) indicate message deprecation.
